Ed Green is president of EH Green Motors Incorporated in Odem, Texas.
For 73 years, the Green family has run the dealership near Corpus Christi.
Ed Green's grandfather opened the business in 1936, the year Chrysler released the four-door Wingmaster and the Imperial Airflow C10 sedan.
Last month, Ed Green received a United Parcel Service letter with the bad news: Chrysler was pulling the plug on his dealership.
And Mr. Green joins us now from the dealership.
Welcome to the program, sir.
Hi.
Now, you're in your office, as we have this conversation, but walk me through the dealership.
What's going on there right now and what's the mood like?
Well, a lot of the employees, we have some that are just super loyal and faithful and they're very mad about not being able to work for us.
They enjoyed working for us.
A couple of our mechanics have stuck by us until the very end, trying to get the work turned out.

A few last-minute jobs done because after today, there will be no more warranty work that Chrysler will reimburse us for, and there will be no more sales that they'll reimburse us for if we sell something.
So, today is the day.
Now, I've never been to Odem, Texas, but I've been reading a little bit about your dealership, and it sounds like you were quite profitable.
Do you have any idea why you were one of the 789 dealers that are on this closure list?
They never have actually released the criteria.
There's been a lot of people blaming - well, it wasn't us.
We didn't make the decision.
So, we really don't know some of the things that entered into the equation.
Obviously would be the fact that we're an older, established dealer and our facility has not been updated.
We control a real fast-growing area in our state.
The Department of Transportation laws say that dealers can't locate within so many miles of one another.
We have the jurisdictional rights to that territory.
Now, once our franchise is gone, then the manufacturer is allowed to move someone into the area of their own choosing.
So, we feel like that may have contributed probably more in our case than the fact that we were underperforming.
How many cars do you still have on the lot?
We're probably down to about eight to 10 units right now, at the most.
We had well over 100 units when we got the letter in May.
Plan to stay in the car business?
I don't think so at this point in time.
But I mean, I learned a long time ago, you never say never to anything.
You got to keep your eyes and ears open because you just don't know what might be available.
But if I was going to have a choice right now, that probably wouldn't be the first choice.
I'm just curious.
After all that you've been through, will you continue to drive a Chrysler product?
Well, yeah, I will for quite some time.
You know, I'm not in a position that I want to just go out and spend a bunch of money on another vehicle.
I have dependable transportation, so I'll probably drive that.
And when I get ready to replace it, I honestly can't say what I'll do.
I mean, my heart and my whole being is with the company that I've been with all my life.
And no matter how upsetting all this is, I - you know, I just don't know if I can drive something else when it gets right down to it.
I've always believed in them, that's why I never took on another brand of products, because we felt like they were the best, and that's what we knew, and that's what we wanted to focus on.
(Soundbite of phone ringing)
Well, Mr. Green, it sounds like a lot of people are trying to reach you there on the phone.
So, I'm going to let you go.
All the best to you.
Thank you so much for talking to us.
Thank you for calling.
We were talking to Ed Green about the closing of his Chrysler dealership.
That's EH Green Motors in Odem, Texas.
The dealership has been in his family for 73 years.
It will close its doors for the final time this evening.

When a family member dies, there are lots of decisions to make, often quickly.
There are funerals to plan, burial plots or urns to buy.
Many businesses want to help families make those decisions.
But an NPR investigation found that some of those businesses steer families toward more expensive choices, sometimes offering the same services at wildly different prices.
Here's NPR's Robert Benincasa.
Ellen Bethea's husband, Archie, died just over a year ago after almost 47 years of marriage.
It was a Wednesday night.
And, you know, we had kind of dozed in and out.
And I told my son - I said, you need to get some rest.
Let me sit with him.
Archie had liver disease.
After a series of tests and meetings with doctors, it had become clear that, despite his family's best hopes, Archie wouldn't recover.
But they signed the papers to remove him from life-support machines.
And she sat alone with him in his hospital room.
As soon as everybody else was asleep, and I was sitting there with him, he passed on.
And I've heard it said before that - you know, that people that are dying - they kind of wait for the right moment.
So I think he kind of waited for me to, you know, be with him.
Soon after that, the staff at her local Jacksonville, Fla., hospital asked Bethea a question she hadn't prepared for.
When we were finishing saying our last goodbyes there, I was immediately asked which funeral home I wanted to use.
Bethea gave the hospital the name of the only funeral home she knew in town, Hardage-Giddens.
She made an appointment there for the next day.
I went with the rest of my family.
My children, my grandchildren were there, too.
They walked out with a bill of over $7,000.
Looking at that bill, one thing might stand out, the cost of Archie's cremation - $3,295.
Here's why that matters.
Elsewhere in Jacksonville, the company that owns Hardage-Giddens sells the same cremations done in the same place and in the same way for less than half that amount.
